title: Stephen Merchant webchat âÂ as it happened | Stage | The Guardian
summary: `` american people are raised to celebrate and champion success . brits seem to be sus of it ''
`` i could live without acting or stand up but i could n't live without writing ''
on the difference between british and american senses of humour .
`` i used to laugh at all that wanky-sounding actor stuff about living the truth of the character , but now i 'm doing it i can see what they mean ''
`` doing this play has been like learning to play a new instrument in a month ''

documents.title: and that 's it for today !
text: joejoego asks : what do you do to switch off ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 2:07pm i mainly watch films and eat in restaurants .
and play chess .
and scour youtube for funny cat videos .
speaking of switching off , i have to end this webchat now .
thanks for your questions - i 'm off to prepare for tonights performance of the mentalists at the wyndham 's theatre .
cheers everyone thanks to stephen for his brilliant answers and to everyone who took part .
until next time !
joejoego asks : are you still developing as a comedian ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 2:03pm i 'm still developing in everything i do .
another reason i 'm doing this play is because i wanted to challenge myself , learn new skills , new ways of working .
it all feeds back into the other work you do .
i only started to feel like i 'm a professional writer and performer ( rather than a keen amateur ) a few years ago .
there 's always new stuff to learn , that 's why i 've enjoyed working with different writers and producers and actors and being in other people 's projects to see what i can learn from them .
skipio asks : have you found that being an actor improves your writing and , is so , why ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:59pm definitely .
and even more so now having done this play .
you hear actors talk about `` what 's my motivation ? ''
- why am i walking over there or shouting here or crying there - and it 's not just them being pretentious .
when you 're acting , what the character does has to make sense at every moment or it seems phoney .
as a writer sometimes you can cheat , and have a character say or do something just because it 's cool or funny or exciting .
but if it 's not true to the character the actor will struggle with it - and it will probably seem phoney to the audience too .
georgia bradbury asks : as a writer myself , the main thing i struggle with is the pacing of the story .
how do you ensure you get the pace right when it comes to writing for tv shows/films etc ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:56pm one of the other things i enjoy when i make a project is being in the editing room .
i 'm ruthless , i will throw out anything that drags the story or slackens the pace in the wrong way .
in the writing , i am more indulgent , knowing i can edit things later and shape the pace in the cutting room .
but i also know that to get things made you can not have flabby scripts .
so be ruthless about editing your own work .
if it does n't move the story on or develop character it probably has to go .
there 's that old writing adage that you have to `` kill your babies '' .
it 's good advice

documents.title: `` american people are raised to celebrate and champion success . brits seem to be sus of it ''
text: antwerpenaar asks : what do you think about the british obsession with putting people on a pedestal and then knocking them down ?
do you think brits are any more nasty/ mean-spirited than people from other countries you have visited/performed in ?
and will use of twitter/facebook make it harder in the future to find good writers for the stage , tv or cinema ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:53pm that does seem like a particularly british thing .
it does n't happen in america in quite the same way .
i think american people are raised to celebrate and champion success .
for whatever reason , brits seem to be sus of it .
there is no shame in saying you 're ambitious in america .
in the uk , saying someone is ambitious is often pejorative .
`` i do n't trust him .
he 's very ambitious '' .
frdougalmcguire asks : i 've been told i look like you .
anyone ever said the same thing to you ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:49pm constantly .
but then , we do look alike .
so you tell me
soleri asks : could you be the next james bond ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:48pm no , but i have n't lost hope in being gadget-man q at some point .
imagine `` pay attention , 007 '' in a west country accent .
it would be like colin pillinger worked for mi6 .
debsie asks : what 's with the beard ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:47pm in my mind it gives me the illusion of masculinity .
lewisdenson asks : are you planning to do another film ?
cemetery junction was really excellent .
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:45pm yes , i 'm working on some screenplays .
i love working on tv shows but the open-endedness of them can sometimes be frustrating .
there is something about the discipline of telling a story in 100 minutes and knowing that you can take people on a journey and give them a satisfying ending that is very gratifying .
writing and directing the hello ladies movie reminded me of that .
susan hood asks : what kind of drunk are you ?
handsy ?
tearful ?
shouty ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:41pm sleepy
keiemm2 asks : celebrity one-on-one basketball , prime-time itv on a saturday night .
you v richard osman .
you in ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:38pm we 've already filmed it .

documents.title: `` i could live without acting or stand up but i could n't live without writing ''
text: kirstyg asks : of all the things you 've worked on , what was the hardest to write and why ?
which comedians working now do you really rate ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:36pm writing is always a mix of the easy and the hard .
sometimes the jokes or ideas are flowing , just as often you 're staring at the wall waiting for inspiration .
but that 's also why writing is the most satisfying of the things i do .
you start with a blank page and by the end you have a world and characters and hopefully something funny or moving or both .
i could live without acting or stand up but i could n't live without writing .
it 's exhilarating when it 's going well .
i recall when ricky and i came up with the moment in the office when tim takes his mic off to ask out dawn .
it was one of those eureka moments and we could n't wait to film it and bring it to life .

documents.title: on the difference between british and american senses of humour
text: mariocavaradossi asks : any thoughts on what makes the british sense of humour unique ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:31pm there is definitely a very dark , cynical , sarcastic edge to british comedy .
people ask me about the difference between british and american comedy and i always think about the 70s sitcom `` whatever happened to the likely lads '' .
it 's great , but if you took away the studio audience laughter it would be quite a bleak existential show about lost youth and growing older .
the lyrics to the opening theme tune are `` oh what happened to you , whatever happened to me / what became of the people we used to be ? ''
it 's a far cry from friends ' `` i 'll be there for you ''

documents.title: `` i used to laugh at all that wanky-sounding actor stuff about living the truth of the character , but now i 'm doing it i can see what they mean ''
text: woobl asks : how are you finding working on stage in a play , as opposed to your previous outings in stand up ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:25pm stand up has given me the experience of being in front of a live crowd but this is my first stage play .
i took on the challenge because i like the idea of staying in character for 90 minutes , unlike in tv where you film in fits and starts and never get any momentum going .
i used to laugh at all that wanky-sounding actor stuff about living the truth of the character , but now i 'm doing it i can see what they mean .
so basically i am a wanker now
sircornflakes asks : do you plan on getting any taller ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:20pm working on it
artist47365 asks : who is stephen merchant , and why is he answering these questions from what appears to be a cloakroom .
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:20pm i 'm an actor , writer , director and comedian .
and i am in a cloakroom
ilgatto asks : moment that changed your life ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:18pm doing a school play and getting a laugh playing a comedy vicar - and thinking , hmm , maybe i could this for a living .
maschruhm asks : do you think people will ever tire of you mentioning your awards on every chat show ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:16pm as a three time bafta winner , i would say yes
thisisdan asks : hi stephen , hello ladies was a brilliant series ! !
how was it making it and is there any chance at all of another series ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:15pm no more series but i hope you saw the movie version we did .
it wraps up the story very nicely .
i liked working in la .
my co-writers were great , i learned a lot from them - and growing up as fan of american films and tv , shooting in hollywood was a thrill .
if nothing else , not having to worry about the weather like you do in england takes a huge pressure off your day
nivlek47 says : i said good morning to you mr merchant at southwark station the other day , after you got off the train .
do you remember me ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:13pm of course .
how could i forget

documents.title: `` doing this play has been like learning to play a new instrument in a month ''
text: liam quane asks : can i ask ; as an actor , what is the best ( funniest/ most helpful ) piece of direction you have been given ?
: ~ ) guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:12pm doing this play has been full of new acting discoveries .
i 've had to learn all the disciplines of theatre acting , which is so different from screen acting .
you have to use your body and voice in a totally different way .
it 's been like learning to play a new instrument in a month .
but our fantastic director abbey has held my hand through the process .
photographer2015 asks : what 's the one question you hope nobody asks you ?
( answering this one is not allowed ) guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:09pm can i borrow money ( this will now lead to lots of people saying `` can i borrow money ? '' )
bethel01 asks : big fan of your work !
are you planning on doing another comedy tour in the future ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:07pm well , i 'm doing this play at the moment which is a completely different live experience than stand up .
the hard job of writing was done by the brilliant playwrite richard bean .
the hardest thing about stand up is finding the time to write and workshop the material on stage .
it 's very very time consuming .

documents.title: a music tune yards
text: mariocavaradossi asks : as someone who enjoyed your music recommendations from the xfm shows ( i 'm thinking of hip hop hooray in particular ) , i was wondering if you have any new music guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:06pm i really like tuneyards .
curious mash up of sounds and styles .
i think she 's great .
salmiakki a .

2h ago 01 do you still have the same opinions on pets that you used to have , ie not really a fan of any of them in general or would you consider getting a pet that is more low maintenance than a dog or a cat ?
guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:05pm i 'd quite like a large great dane called max that i can stride through a park with , shouting `` max , heel '' .
i think i 'd look cool and distinguished .

documents.title: stephen has arrived !
text: here 's proof : stephen merchant , ready to start answering your questions .
beaumont-thomas his fist answer is to jallford , who asked : hi steve , love your comedy !
you did stand-up earlier in your career but then gave it up , was there anything specific that prompted you to go back ?
ps - any chance of getting the gang back together ?
i 'm sure people ask non-stop but the podcasts are still some of the best comedy i 've heard .
what would it take ?
a million bucks on kickstarter ?

guardian contributor stephenmerchant1 07 july 2015 1:04pm i never really enjoyed being on the road and eating ginsters pasties from a service station late at night after a gig in the middle of nowhere .
but i sort of missed the challenge of stand up and eventually started doing little pub gigs near my house and fell in love with it again

documents.title: post your questions for stephen merchant
text: stephen merchant is one of the most instantly recognisable figures in british comedy , and not just for his height .
his collaborations with ricky gervais the office , cemetery junction , their hit podcast series are as influential as they are adored , and their success helped merchant launch a career in the us .
he became a viral sensation for his lip-syncing performances on us tv , and turned his standup tour hello ladies into a show for hbo .
he 's now back in the uk , making his west end debut in the mentalists .
it 's a comic and politically charged two-hander written by richard bean , known for one man , two guvnors , with merchant playing a fanatical man filming his personal manifesto to change the world .
ahead of the play opening this month , he 's joining us to answer your questions about it and anything else in his career , in a live webchat from 1pm bst onwards on tuesday 7 july .
post your questions in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The star of The Office and new play The Mentalists joined us to answer your questions catch up with his answers here, from pets to music to the moment that changed his life, via reflections on stand-up and why writing is the most satisfying of the things he does.
